title: AI-Powered Robots Now Performing Complex Surgeries
description: Stanford researchers developed an AI system that outperforms human doctors in diagnosing complex medical cases.
content: AI integration into robotic surgery is transforming how complex procedures are performed. Traditional robotic systems, like the da Vinci Surgical System, have already improved surgical precision and control. However, the addition of AI allows these systems to analyze vast amounts of surgical data, recognize patterns, and assist surgeons in real-time. This capability enhances decision-making, reduces human error, and allows for continuous learning, making the robots smarter with each procedure.

title: Apple Unveils Foldable iPhone with Holographic Display
description: Researchers achieve quantum supremacy with new 256-qubit processor that cracked RSA-2048.
content: Apple is reportedly planning to launch its first foldableiPhone -- the iPhone Fold in 2026. Now, the latest leaks related tothe device have revealed some crucial information. According to Taiwaneseresearch firm TrendForce, the upcoming foldable iPhone could sporta 7.8-inch inner display and a 5.5-inch outer display. These numbers matchearlier predictions from well-known analyst Ming-Chi Kuo.In comparison, Samsung’s latest foldable phone the Galaxy Z Fold 7 currently comes with an 8-inch inner display and a 6.5-inch outer screen. It means the upcoming foldable device from Apple will be a little thicker than the Samsung Galaxy Z Fold 7.Apple iPhone Fold Launch Timeline And PriceThe foldable iPhone is expected to launch in the second half of 2026, with a possible debut in September. In terms of pricing, according to a report by MacRumors, the iPhone Fold will reach the US shores at a price range between $1,800 to $2,000. That converts to between Rs 1,54,676 to Rs 1,71,862.

title: Meta’s New VR Headset Reads Brain Signals for Control
description: First human trials for brain-chip implants will begin next month with 10 participants.
content: Imagine scrolling through your social media feed, sending a message, or skipping a song without tapping a button or resorting to voice commandsjustasubtletwitchofyour hand. That’s the wild promise of Meta’s latest research, and it’s not some distant sci-fi dream.Thanks to a new study published in Nature,we’regettinga sneak peek at how augmented reality (AR) glasses could soon read your intentions before you even fully act on them.Meta’s Reality Labs has been quietly working onatech called surface electromyography (sEMG), which sounds complicated but boils down to one simple idea: detecting the tiny electrical signals your muscles send when youeventhink about moving. Instead of waving your arms around or using a bulky controller, you slip on a lightweight armband. Trained on data from thousands of people, thesystem deciphers minute electrical patterns that the brain sends to your fingers.One test user typed at over 20 words per minute just thinking the stroke motions. The teamsmashed the key hurdles: generalization across users (so it doesn’t need per‑person calibration), consistent gesture recognition, and handwriting decoding, all embedded ina wristband-style interface.The big deal here is speed and subtlety. Current AR controls rely on voice, hand tracking (needs big gestures), or clunky remotes. In its Nature paper, Meta showed off Orion, a prototype wristband that predicted gestures with scary accuracy, even when people barely moved. It worked while typing on a keyboard or holding a coffee without needing to pause your life to interact with tech.

title: ChatGPT-5 Released with Real-Time Learning Capabilities
description: Stanford researchers developed an AI system that outperforms human doctors in diagnosing complex medical cases.
content: In a groundbreaking study published in Nature Medicine, artificial intelligence has demonstrated remarkable capabilities in diagnosing rare diseases that often baffle physicians. The system, called MediAI, analyzed over 100,000 medical cases and achieved 94% diagnostic accuracy compared to 65% for human specialists. How the Technology Works The AI cross-references patient symptoms with a database of over 10 million medical records, searching for patterns humans might miss. It's not replacing doctors, but augmenting their capabilitiesexplains lead researcher Dr. Sarah Chen. Real-World ImpactIn clinical trials at Mayo Clinic, the system reduced diagnostic timfrom an average of 4 weeks to just 48 hours for complex cases. Early detection of rare conditions like Guillain-Barré syndrome has already savedlives. Ethical Considerations While promising, experts warn about data privacy concerns and the need for human oversight. The FDA is currently reviewing the system for broader clinical use.
